page.title: 07 LOCAL HISTORY i
page.content: { BARNES}was mentioned in the Domesday Book and a fire in St.Mary's Church in 1978 revealed a previously concealed Norman doorway which dates the church back to the 1100s. Rose Cottage and Millbourne House are the oldest houses, both close to the village pond (first reference to a Millbourne in the church - 1415). Part of the manor of Wimbledon, MORTLAKE did not have a church of its own until Tudor times. The villagers who farmed on what is now Richmond Park used the chapel of the Archbishop of Canterbury's Palace (demolished after the Reformation) where the brewery now stands. A font, bearing the arms of an Archbishop, stands in St. Mary's. In 1619 the famous Mortlake Tapestry works opened. They later acquired the Raphael cartoons for copying.
